values.description:
I'm getting cmake warnings on my mac (cmake 3.2.1) and also on [jenkins homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/59/consoleFull):
~~~
CMake Warning (dev) at cmake/SDFUtils.cmake:138 (add_dependencies):
  Policy CMP0046 is not set: Error on non-existent dependency in
  add_dependencies.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0046" for policy details.
  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this warning.

  The dependency target "tinyxml" of target
  "INTEGRATION_fixed_joint_reduction" does not exist.
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  test/integration/CMakeLists.txt:20 (sdf_build_tests)
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.
~~~

I'm pretty sure there is no target `tinyxml`, since the library is either found externally on UNIX or the tinyxml source code is compiled with each executable. I believe there is no tinyxml library or target ever created. So it should be safe to remove it from the dependency list.
values.title: Remove tinyxml from dependency list

summary.raw:
I'm getting cmake warnings on my mac (cmake 3.2.1) and also on [jenkins homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/59/consoleFull):
~~~
CMake Warning (dev) at cmake/SDFUtils.cmake:138 (add_dependencies):
  Policy CMP0046 is not set: Error on non-existent dependency in
  add_dependencies.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0046" for policy details.
  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this warning.

  The dependency target "tinyxml" of target
  "INTEGRATION_fixed_joint_reduction" does not exist.
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  test/integration/CMakeLists.txt:20 (sdf_build_tests)
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.
~~~

I'm pretty sure there is no target `tinyxml`, since the library is either found externally on UNIX or the tinyxml source code is compiled with each executable. I believe there is no tinyxml library or target ever created. So it should be safe to remove it from the dependency list.
summary.html:
I'm getting cmake warnings on my mac (cmake 3.2.1) and also on jenkins homebrew:

CMake Warning (dev) at cmake/SDFUtils.cmake:138 (add_dependencies):
  Policy CMP0046 is not set: Error on non-existent dependency in
  add_dependencies.  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0046" for policy details.
  Use the cmake_policy command to set the policy and suppress this warning.

  The dependency target "tinyxml" of target
  "INTEGRATION_fixed_joint_reduction" does not exist.
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  test/integration/CMakeLists.txt:20 (sdf_build_tests)
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.

I'm pretty sure there is no target tinyxml, since the library is either found externally on UNIX or the tinyxml source code is compiled with each executable. I believe there is no tinyxml library or target ever created. So it should be safe to remove it from the dependency list.

values.description:
For some reason, xmlschema.rb does not have the executable bit when cloning the repo on Windows. That makes Windows to complain (open a new Window and ask for user interaction) when trying to run xmlchema.

Explicit call to ruby seems to fix the problem
values.title: Explicit call to ruby to fix the run of xmlschema on windows

summary.raw:
For some reason, xmlschema.rb does not have the executable bit when cloning the repo on Windows. That makes Windows to complain (open a new Window and ask for user interaction) when trying to run xmlchema.

Explicit call to ruby seems to fix the problem
summary.html:
For some reason, xmlschema.rb does not have the executable bit when cloning the repo on Windows. That makes Windows to complain (open a new Window and ask for user interaction) when trying to run xmlchema.

Explicit call to ruby seems to fix the problem

values.description:
When cloning on Windows, the executable bit seems not to being preserved. As a consequence of this, the check_test_ran failed since Windows does not consider the check_test_ran script as program.

@scpeters fixed it by explicitly calling python.
values.title: Fix check_test_ran on windows

summary.raw:
When cloning on Windows, the executable bit seems not to being preserved. As a consequence of this, the check_test_ran failed since Windows does not consider the check_test_ran script as program.

@scpeters fixed it by explicitly calling python.
summary.html:
When cloning on Windows, the executable bit seems not to being preserved. As a consequence of this, the check_test_ran failed since Windows does not consider the check_test_ran script as program.

@scpeters fixed it by explicitly calling python.

values.description:
Per @nkoenig's request in [gazebo PR 1557](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1557/presetmanager-part-2-command-line-sdf/diff), I added an accessor to Element that returns a `boost::any`. It calls a new accessor in `Param` maps the `type_info` of the parameter to cast its `boost::variant` value to the right type.

I tried to figure out a fancier, shorter way to cast the `boost::variant` in Param to a `boost::any` but it didn't seem to work, so I went with this more verbose solution.
values.title: Added boost::any accessor for Param and Element

summary.raw:
Per @nkoenig's request in [gazebo PR 1557](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1557/presetmanager-part-2-command-line-sdf/diff), I added an accessor to Element that returns a `boost::any`. It calls a new accessor in `Param` maps the `type_info` of the parameter to cast its `boost::variant` value to the right type.

I tried to figure out a fancier, shorter way to cast the `boost::variant` in Param to a `boost::any` but it didn't seem to work, so I went with this more verbose solution.
summary.html:
Per @nkoenig's request in gazebo PR 1557, I added an accessor to Element that returns a boost::any. It calls a new accessor in Param maps the type_info of the parameter to cast its boost::variant value to the right type.

I tried to figure out a fancier, shorter way to cast the boost::variant in Param to a boost::any but it didn't seem to work, so I went with this more verbose solution.

values.title: urdf format support in sdf
values.reason: Users of libsdformat should expect the sdf format. If we merge this in, any existing user of libsdformat will have to suddenly implement another code path that handles urdf. More details in comments.

values.description:
[Jenkins failure on default](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-default-devel-homebrew-amd64/1/) is fixed by including `sstream` in `Types.hh`. I apparently never re-tested pull request #160 on OS X after it had a new commit added.

There's also some warning fixes.

@\_jrivero_ We should consider re-running all the `sdformat-any-` jenkins jobs for each new commit to an active pull request, since the jobs are pretty short (much shorter than gazebo). Would it be hard to add this to bitjen?
values.title: Fix osx build (#89): include sstream in Types.hh, and fix some warnings

summary.raw:
[Jenkins failure on default](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-default-devel-homebrew-amd64/1/) is fixed by including `sstream` in `Types.hh`. I apparently never re-tested pull request #160 on OS X after it had a new commit added.

There's also some warning fixes.

@\_jrivero_ We should consider re-running all the `sdformat-any-` jenkins jobs for each new commit to an active pull request, since the jobs are pretty short (much shorter than gazebo). Would it be hard to add this to bitjen?
summary.html:
Jenkins failure on default is fixed by including sstream in Types.hh. I apparently never re-tested pull request #160 on OS X after it had a new commit added.

There's also some warning fixes.

@_jrivero_ We should consider re-running all the sdformat-any- jenkins jobs for each new commit to an active pull request, since the jobs are pretty short (much shorter than gazebo). Would it be hard to add this to bitjen?

values.description:
Aside from minor typo correction in header files (`\bried` -> `\brief`), and changing include files, this is a direct copy paste. It's easiest to see by melding `SDFImpl.hh` and `SDF.cc` from the default branch with `Element.cc/hh` in this branch.

This is part of pull request #167, which was really big, so I wanted to split it up into some smaller chunks.
values.title: Move Element class to its own header and source files

summary.raw:
Aside from minor typo correction in header files (`\bried` -> `\brief`), and changing include files, this is a direct copy paste. It's easiest to see by melding `SDFImpl.hh` and `SDF.cc` from the default branch with `Element.cc/hh` in this branch.

This is part of pull request #167, which was really big, so I wanted to split it up into some smaller chunks.
summary.html:
Aside from minor typo correction in header files (\bried -> \brief), and changing include files, this is a direct copy paste. It's easiest to see by melding SDFImpl.hh and SDF.cc from the default branch with Element.cc/hh in this branch.

This is part of pull request #167, which was really big, so I wanted to split it up into some smaller chunks.

values.description:
This will facilitate setting a user camera to use orthographic or perspective projections.

You can try this out with gazebo's `camera_ortho` branch. See `worlds/ortho.world`, and `test/worlds/ortho_box.world`.
values.title: Add projection type to gui camera

You can try this out with gazebo's `camera_ortho` branch. See `worlds/ortho.world`, and `test/worlds/ortho_box.world`.

values.description:
The meta element is a place to store information about their parent element. In this case, I've added a `<meta>` element to visuals which contains a `<layer>` element. 

Gazebo will use `<layers>` to turn on/off different visuals. See [this video](https://youtu.be/5C-TW6m-COU) as an example. You can play with this yourself using the "layers" branch of gazebo with the "shapes_layers.world".
values.title: Adding meta information to visuals

summary.raw:
The meta element is a place to store information about their parent element. In this case, I've added a `<meta>` element to visuals which contains a `<layer>` element. 

Gazebo will use `<layers>` to turn on/off different visuals. See [this video](https://youtu.be/5C-TW6m-COU) as an example. You can play with this yourself using the "layers" branch of gazebo with the "shapes_layers.world".
summary.html:
The meta element is a place to store information about their parent element. In this case, I've added a <meta> element to visuals which contains a <layer> element.

Gazebo will use <layers> to turn on/off different visuals. See this video as an example. You can play with this yourself using the "layers" branch of gazebo with the "shapes_layers.world".

values.description:
Homebrew just upgraded to boost 1.58. There is an added feature that causes a [test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-default-devel-homebrew-amd64/15/testReport/). In 1.57 and earlier, hexadecimal values couldn't be parsed to floating point variables, while now it appears that they can be parsed. So I check the boost version and change the expectations accordingly.
~~~
src/UNIT_Param_TEST 
[==========] Running 6 tests from 2 test cases.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 5 tests from Param
[ RUN      ] Param.Bool
[       OK ] Param.Bool (1 ms)
[ RUN      ] Param.HexInt
Error [Param.cc:330] Out of range. Unable to set value [0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff ] for key[key].
[       OK ] Param.HexInt (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Param.HexUInt
Error [Param.cc:330] Out of range. Unable to set value [0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff ] for key[key].
[       OK ] Param.HexUInt (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Param.HexFloat
/Users/scpeters/ws/sdformat/src/sdformat/src/Param_TEST.cc:148: Failure
Value of: floatParam.SetFromString("0x01")
  Actual: true
Expected: false
/Users/scpeters/ws/sdformat/src/sdformat/src/Param_TEST.cc:150: Failure
Value of: 0.0f
  Actual: 0
Expected: value
Which is: 1
Error [Param.cc:330] Out of range. Unable to set value [1.0e100 ] for key[key].
[  FAILED  ] Param.HexFloat (0 ms)
[ RUN      ] Param.HexDouble
/Users/scpeters/ws/sdformat/src/sdformat/src/Param_TEST.cc:170: Failure
Value of: doubleParam.SetFromString("0x01")
  Actual: true
Expected: false
/Users/scpeters/ws/sdformat/src/sdformat/src/Param_TEST.cc:172: Failure
Value of: 0.0
  Actual: 0
Expected: value
Which is: 1
Error [Param.cc:330] Out of range. Unable to set value [1.0e1000 ] for key[key].
[  FAILED  ] Param.HexDouble (1 ms)
[----------] 5 tests from Param (2 ms total)

[----------] 1 test from SetFromString
[ RUN      ] SetFromString.Decimals
[       OK ] SetFromString.Decimals (0 ms)
[----------] 1 test from SetFromString (0 ms total)

[----------] Global test environment tear-down
[==========] 6 tests from 2 test cases ran. (2 ms total)
[  PASSED  ] 4 tests.
[  FAILED  ] 2 tests, listed below:
[  FAILED  ] Param.HexFloat
[  FAILED  ] Param.HexDouble

 2 FAILED TESTS
~~~
values.title: Fix boost 1.58 test failure

Homebrew just upgraded to boost 1.58. There is an added feature that causes a [test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-default-devel-homebrew-amd64/15/testReport/). In 1.57 and earlier, hexadecimal values couldn't be parsed to floating point variables, while now it appears that they can be parsed. So I check the boost version and change the expectations accordingly.

values.description: This is the only `boost::mutex` in sdformat. It's one of the easier pieces of boost to remove because it doesn't affect API, unlike `boost::shared_ptr`.

values.description:
This should address:

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/185/inserting-a-bad-sdf-model-does-not-do

I had to fix a few of the other sdformat tests which had invalid XML. I have not tested this against Gazebo's test suite.

I was also unsure whether or not an XML parsing error should return or continue or otherwise abort here:

#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/new?source=xml_parsing_error_fix&t=1#Lsrc/parser.ccT622

So, I'll need feedback on that and then I'll update it accordingly.
values.title: Fix detection of XML parsing errors

summary.raw:
This should address:

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/185/inserting-a-bad-sdf-model-does-not-do

I had to fix a few of the other sdformat tests which had invalid XML. I have not tested this against Gazebo's test suite.

I was also unsure whether or not an XML parsing error should return or continue or otherwise abort here:

#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/new?source=xml_parsing_error_fix&t=1#Lsrc/parser.ccT622

So, I'll need feedback on that and then I'll update it accordingly.
summary.html:
This should address:

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/185/inserting-a-bad-sdf-model-does-not-do

I had to fix a few of the other sdformat tests which had invalid XML. I have not tested this against Gazebo's test suite.

I was also unsure whether or not an XML parsing error should return or continue or otherwise abort here:

#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/new?source=xml_parsing_error_fix&t=1#Lsrc/parser.ccT622

So, I'll need feedback on that and then I'll update it accordingly.

values.description: While working on another PR, I noticed that this file handle would not be closed in all cases. So I changed the logic to ensure that if it is successfully opened it is closed. It also allowed me to make a more precise error message when the file opened, but `initFile` fails.
values.title: improve logic to ensure that a file is closed

values.description:
The changes are: 

* make the `axis` element an optional child of `joint`. 
* add `fixed` to the list of supported joint types. 

For more information, please check Gazebo issue 1278. [1]

[1] : https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1278/support-fixed-joint-types-in-gazebo
values.title: Support for fixed joints

values.description:
Resubmission of pull request #189.

The matching push is on line 226.

Fixing this exposed a bunch of uses of deprecated `sdf::Vector3`, `sdf::Quaternion`, and `sdf::Pose` variables, so I had to fix those warnings as well. The side-by-side diff viewer is recommended.
values.title: Fix pragma from pull request #173 (push should actually be pop)

values.reason: worked with clang, fails with gcc

values.description:
Resubmission of pull request #189 and pull request #195.

The matching push is on line 226.

Fixing this exposed a bunch of uses of deprecated `sdf::Vector3`, `sdf::Quaternion`, and `sdf::Pose` variables, so I had to fix those warnings as well. The side-by-side diff viewer is recommended.

Also, I was observing [build failures with gcc](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-any-devel-utopic-amd64/52/) that I fixed by changing the location of the `#pragma` statements (0f36c8e). It worked either way on clang. I wonder if it's a gcc bug.
values.title: Fix pragma from pull request #173 (push should actually be pop)

summary.raw:
Resubmission of pull request #189 and pull request #195.

The matching push is on line 226.

Fixing this exposed a bunch of uses of deprecated `sdf::Vector3`, `sdf::Quaternion`, and `sdf::Pose` variables, so I had to fix those warnings as well. The side-by-side diff viewer is recommended.

Also, I was observing [build failures with gcc](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/SDFormat/job/sdformat-any-devel-utopic-amd64/52/) that I fixed by changing the location of the `#pragma` statements (0f36c8e). It worked either way on clang. I wonder if it's a gcc bug.
summary.html:
Resubmission of pull request #189 and pull request #195.

The matching push is on line 226.

Fixing this exposed a bunch of uses of deprecated sdf::Vector3, sdf::Quaternion, and sdf::Pose variables, so I had to fix those warnings as well. The side-by-side diff viewer is recommended.

Also, I was observing build failures with gcc that I fixed by changing the location of the #pragma statements (0f36c8e). It worked either way on clang. I wonder if it's a gcc bug.
